greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest integer that, when divided by any divisor of A025487(n), yields a member of A025487.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: If A025487(n) = Product prime(i)^e(i), then a(n) = Product A002110(i)^e(i). I.e., a(n) = A108951(A025487(n)).
If A025487(n) = Product A002110(i)^e(i), then a(n) = Product A006939(i)^e(i).
example: For any divisor d of 6 (d = 1, 2, 3, 6), 12/d (12, 6, 4, 2) is always a member of A025487. 12 is the smallest number with this relationship to 6; therefore, since 6 = A025487(4), a(4) = 12.
results.author: _Matthew Vandermast_, Nov 30 2010
